pageData.text: An object moving in a circle, experiencing uniform circular motion, is accelerating even though the magnitude of its linear velocity is constant; this is because the direction of the velocity is continually changing. The resulting acceleration, called <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button>, is defined as moving or tending to move toward a center. The force that produces centripetal acceleration is called <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> and is sometimes referred as a center-seeking force. In this investigation, you will explore the factors that affect linear velocity, centripetal acceleration, and centripetal force for a mass moving in a horizontal circle.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Timing device, such as a stopwatch or stopwatch app
A cell phone or other mobile device capable of recording video
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photographs
Graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets
A scientific calculator capable of computing inverse trigonometric functions (used in data analysis portion of activity)
Optional, but recommended: a volunteer to assist you rotating the moving mass or with timing.

Preparation - 20 minutes 
Activity 1: Exploring Centripetal Acceleration Varying the Radius of the Moving Mass, m - 30 minutes 
		Varying the Hanging Mass, M - 20 minutes 
		Data Analysis - 30 minutes 
Extension Activity 1 - 60 minutes

Preparation - 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Exploring Kinematics - 65 minutes 
Extension Activity 1 - 20 minutes

text: Calculate the theoretical linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Measure the <button class='glossary-text'>angular frequency</button> of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Experimentally determine the linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Calculate the percent error in the linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle by comparing the theoretical and experimental values.
Evaluate how the <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button> of a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the radius of the circle.
Evaluate how the centripetal acceleration of a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by varying the hanging mass.
Evaluate how the <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> of a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the radius of the circle.
Evaluate how the centripetal force of a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by varying the hanging mass.

pageData.text: Many sports rely on the physics of <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button>. Figure skating in particular features many types of rotating jumps, such as axels, loops and lutzes, which are affected by the initial tangential velocity of the skater. Skaters have gradually started performing more rotations in the air during these jumps, with elite skaters often performing quadruple turns when triple jumps were considered groundbreaking just a few decades ago. Many of these advances have come from looking at and better understanding the physics that make these jumps possible. Exercise scientists look at specific factors, like what horizontal/linear velocity will allow for the highest <button class='glossary-text'>angular velocity</button> and angular momentum and how skaters can decrease their moment of inertia, to help skaters perform these more complex jumps<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Some scientists have started experimenting with skates fitted with sensors and detectors in order to better understand all of the forces at play and maximize skaters’ performance. Many scientists believe that quintuple jumps, or jumps with five rotations, could be physically possible for skaters if they can work out the necessary initial conditions to perform these feats.

1Lewis, T. (2022, February 14). How Olympic Figure Skaters Break Records with Physics. Scientific American.https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-olympic-figure-skaters-break-records-with-physics/

pageData.desc: A skater in the middle of a rotating jump over an ice skating rink.
pageData.altText: A skater in the middle of a rotating jump over an ice skating rink.

pageData.text: , a, is a vector quantity with units of m/s2 (meters per second per second) and is calculated using the relationship in Equation 1. Acceleration can occur due to the change in the magnitude of the velocity vector, v, and/or the change in the direction of the velocity vector.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: vector acceleration equals begin fraction begin parenthesis vector velocity sub f minus vector velocity sub f end parentheses over delta time end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 1: vector acceleration equals begin fraction begin parenthesis vector velocity sub f minus vector velocity sub f end parentheses over delta time end fraction

pageData.text: Both types of changes in velocity are produced by an unbalanced force as stated in <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s first law of motion</button>: an object at rest or in uniform motion will continue to be at rest or in uniform motion unless acted on by a net external force.

If an object of mass, m, is moving in a circle at a constant linear speed, v; its direction is continually changing resulting in an acceleration. This is called and is defined as moving or tending to move toward a center. The force that produces centripetal acceleration is called and is sometimes referred to as a center-seeking force. Centripetal force is a vector quantity with units of N, Newtons, directed along the radius of the circle toward the center.
Consider the object of mass, m, moving along a circular path with a radius, r, at an , f, as shown in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Mass, m, moving in a circle
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Mass, m, moving in a circle

pageData.text: The , ω, is equal to the rate of change of , θ, and has units of radians per second; rad/s. Angular velocity is a vector quantity directed in the same direction as the angular displacement; the relationship for calculating angular velocity, ω, is shown in Equation 2.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: omega equals begin fraction delta theta over delta t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 2: omega equals begin fraction delta theta over delta t end fraction

pageData.text: The , f, corresponds to the angular speed and is a scalar quantity with units of Hertz, Hz; a measure of cycles per second or revolutions per second. The conversion between angular frequency, f, and , ω, is 2π radians, shown in Equation 3.

pageData.desc: Equation 3: omega equals 2 pi f
pageData.altText: Equation 3: omega equals 2 pi f

pageData.text: The T measures the time for one cycle or revolution and is the reciprocal of the angular frequency, f. The unit for period is seconds and Equation 4 illustrates its relation to angular frequency.

pageData.desc: Equation 4: T equals 1 over f
pageData.altText: Equation 4: T equals 1 over f

pageData.text: Combining Equation 3 and Equation 4 gives the relationship between angular velocity, ω, and the period, T, shown in Equation 5.

pageData.desc: Equation 5: omega equals begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 5: omega equals begin fraction 2 pi over T end fraction

pageData.text: The linear (tangential) velocity, v, along the circumference of the circular path of a rotating object can be determined from the definition of average velocity, which is distance divided by time. Equation 6 shows various ways to determine linear (tangential) velocity with each relationship having a dependence on the distance the rotating object is from the center of rotation (radius, r).

pageData.desc: Equation 6: v equals begin fraction distance over time end fraction equals begin fraction circumference over period end fraction equals begin fraction 2pi r over T end fraction equals 2 pi f r equals w r
pageData.altText: Equation 6: v equals begin fraction distance over time end fraction equals begin fraction circumference over period end fraction equals begin fraction 2pi r over T end fraction equals 2 pi f r equals w r

pageData.text: The mass, m, shown in , is rotating with uniform circular motion at a constant f, in a circle with a radius, r. The direction of the mass is constantly changing resulting in an acceleration directed toward the center of the circular path and along the radius; this is called , ac. The derivation of the formula for centripetal acceleration is shown in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Location of an object moving in a circular path
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Location of an object moving in a circular path

pageData.text: An object is moving in the direction indicated by θ; with the position of the particle at some arbitrary time, t, given by Equation 7.

pageData.desc: Equation 7: r equals x i plus y j equals r cosine theta times i plus r sine theta j
pageData.altText: Equation 7: r equals x i plus y j equals r cosine theta times i plus r sine theta j

pageData.text: Using the ω relationship θ = ωt, the position of the particle at some arbitrary time t is shown in Equation 8:

pageData.desc: Equation 8: r equals x times vector i hat plus y vector j hat equals r times cosine of omega times t times vector i + r times sine of omega times t times vector j hat
pageData.altText: Equation 8: r equals x times vector i hat plus y vector j hat equals r times cosine of omega times t times vector i + r times sine of omega times t times vector j hat

pageData.text: From this relationship, you can extract the expression of the radial unit vector in Cartesian coordinates, shown in Equation 9:

pageData.desc: Equation 9: r hat equals begin fraction r over absolute value r end fraction equals cosine of i plus sine of j equals cosine omega t plus sine omega t j
pageData.altText: Equation 9: r hat equals begin fraction r over absolute value r end fraction equals cosine of i plus sine of j equals cosine omega t plus sine omega t j

pageData.text: The velocity is the derivation of the position vector with respect to time.

pageData.desc: Equation 10: v equals begin fraction d r over d t end fraction equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket cosine omega t i plus sine omega t j end bracket equals
pageData.altText: Equation 10: v equals begin fraction d r over d t end fraction equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket cosine omega t i plus sine omega t j end bracket equals

pageData.text: To find acceleration, differentiate the velocity equation with respect to time, t.

pageData.desc: Equation 11: a equals begin fraction dv over dt equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket minus r omega sine omega t i plus r omega cosine omega t j end bracket equals minus r omega sup 2 cosine omega t i minus r omega sup 2 sine omega t j
pageData.altText: Equation 11: a equals begin fraction dv over dt equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket minus r omega sine omega t i plus r omega cosine omega t j end bracket equals minus r omega sup 2 cosine omega t i minus r omega sup 2 sine omega t j

pageData.text: Substitute the relationship from in Equation 11 to get the , ac.

pageData.desc: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat
pageData.altText: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat

pageData.text: The Equation 12 relationship indicates the centripetal acceleration has a magnitude v2/r and points toward the center of the circular path.
According to , there is a net external force causing the centripetal acceleration, ac; this is the , Fc = m ac as shown in Equation 13.

pageData.desc: Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction

pageData.question: Which of the following describes the variables used to calculate the centripetal acceleration of an object?

options.text: radius of the circular path, linear velocity of the object as it rotates
radius of the circular path, mass of the rotating object
linear velocity of the object, mass of the rotating object
mass of the rotating object, gravity constant
linear velocity of the object, angular velocity of the object

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Both the radius of the circular path and the linear velocity of the object as it rotates are used to calculate the centripetal acceleration of the object.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes the variables used to calculate the centripetal force of an object?

options.text: radius of the circular path, linear velocity of the object, mass of the object
radius of the circular path, mass of the object
linear velocity of the object, mass of the object
radius of the circular path, angular velocity of the object
only the linear velocity of the object

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The radius of the circular path, linear velocity of the object as it rotates, and the mass of the rotating object are all needed to calculate the centripetal force.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Equation 12 relationship indicates the centripetal acceleration has a magnitude v2/r and points toward the center of the circular path. According to Newton’s second law of motion, there is a net external force causing the centripetal acceleration, ac; this is the centripetal force, Fc = mac as shown in Equation 13.

img.alt: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat
Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Equation 12 relationship indicates the centripetal acceleration has a magnitude v2/r and points toward the center of the circular path. According to Newton’s second law of motion, there is a net external force causing the centripetal acceleration, ac; this is the centripetal force, Fc = mac as shown in Equation 13.

img.alt: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat
Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will be examining the relationships in <button class='resource-text'>Equations 12 and 13</button>. First, you will evaluate how the <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button> experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changes in the radius of the circle. Then, you will evaluate how the <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the radius of the circle.

This investigation and extension activity will use an apparatus like , where the centripetal force is supplied by the weight of a hanging mass, M. The weight of this hanging mass, M keeps the smaller mass m moving in a horizontal circle and is determined using . Then, the centripetal force experienced by the moving mass, m, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, as shown in Equation 15.

pageData.desc: Equation 14: Weight equals F sub w equals M times g
pageData.altText: Equation 14: Weight equals F sub w equals M times g

pageData.desc: Equation 15: F sub c equals F sub w
pageData.altText: Equation 15: F sub c equals F sub w

pageData.text: The centripetal acceleration and force investigation will examine the relationship of Equation 15 by evaluating how the centripetal acceleration experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the hanging mass, M. A free body diagram of the forces acting on the mass moving in a circle is shown in Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: forces acting on a mass moving in a circle
pageData.altText: Figure 3: forces acting on a mass moving in a circle

pageData.text: The tension in the string, T, is equal to the weight of the hanging mass, M g. The investigation will also evaluate how the centripetal force experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the hanging mass, M.

An expression for the linear (tangential) velocity, v, shown in Equation 16 is found by setting the equal to the weight of the hanging mass (). Replace Fc with the equivalent expression in and FW with the equivalent expression of ; then solve for linear (tangential) velocity, v.

pageData.desc: Equation 16: begin fraction m v squared over r end fraction equals M g yields v squared equals begin fraction M g r over m end fraction yields v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 16: begin fraction m v squared over r end fraction equals M g yields v squared equals begin fraction M g r over m end fraction yields v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root

pageData.text: The expression in Equation 16 for the linear (tangential) velocity represents the theoretical value of v given the setup of an apparatus like the one shown in with hanging mass M, moving mass m, and radius, r.

The experimental value for the linear (tangential) velocity will be determined by measuring the time, t, for N = 10 revolutions of mass, m, rotating in a circular path of radius, r; this is expressed in Equation 17.

pageData.desc: Equation 17: v equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 10 end parentheses times 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 20 end parentheses pi r over t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 17: v equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 10 end parentheses times 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 20 end parentheses pi r over t end fraction

pageData.text: This experimental value for the linear (tangential) velocity, v, will be compared to the theoretical value determined in Equation 16 by calculating the percent error. Graphical analysis will be used to evaluate the and centripetal force relationships of , along with a comparison between centripetal force and weight of the hanging mass. In the extension activity you will further investigate by changing the moving mass, m, to see the effect this change has on centripetal acceleration and centripetal force.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, determine the mass of the washers, construct the apparatus, measure the string and test the apparatus. In activity 1, spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. Then, place a paper clip at the specified length to shorten the radius. Repeat the procedure at all specified radii. Next, reset the apparatus, add an additional washer and record the mass. Then, spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. Do this for 2, 3 and 4 washers. Next, calculate the percent difference for the experimental and theoretical velocities, Ve2 and centripetal acceleration. Finally, complete four graphs and analyze the data of each: r versus Ve2, centripetal acceleration versus Ve2, r versus m Ve2 and Ve2 versus centripetal force. Proceed to the extension activity if it is assigned.

A map of the procedural workflow for the extension activity for this investigation.  In the extension activity, you will reset the appartatus. Then, you will measure the mass of the small washers and add an additional small washer to the apparatus as a moving mass. Next, you will spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. When you have completed this for 2, 3 and 4 small wahsers, you will then calculate the percent difference for the experimental and theoretical velocities, Ve2 and centripetal acceleration.  Finally, complete two graphs and analyze the data of each: centripetal acceleration versus Ve2, and r/m versus  Ve2.

Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.
pageData.desc: goggle symbol
pageData.altText: goggle symbol

pageData.text: Safety precautions must be taken, as the experiment involves rotating masses in a horizontal circle.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

You may have learned manual or approximate techniques for finding the best-fit slope of a line. As well as the built-in regression functions on most graphing calculators, spreadsheet software—such as Excel, the free version LibreOffice, and Google Sheets—can all use the correct regression technique to find the best-fit slope. Make sure that you understand what type of data analysis tools your lab instructor wants you to use in this analysis.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is true about an object rotating in a circular path at constant speed?

options.text: The object is experiencing centripetal acceleration.
The net force acting on the object is zero.
The object is not accelerating and experiences zero net force.
None of these statements are true.

assestmentData.question: When a car travels around a curve, which of the following provides the force necessary to keep it on the curve?
If the radius of a circle doubles but the angular frequency stays the same, by what factor does the centripetal acceleration change?

options.text: It is reduced by a factor of three.
It increases by a factor of four.

assestmentData.question: If the mass of a rotating object is reduced by half but the radius of the circle and the angular frequency stay the same, by what factor does the centripetal force change?

options.text: It is reduced by a factor of three.
It increases by a factor of four.

assestmentData.question: An object is rotating in a circular path in uniform, constant motion.  The time it takes for 10 revolutions is 4.16 seconds.  What is the angular velocity of the object?

An object is rotating in a circular path in uniform, constant motion. The radius of the circular path is 0.250 m. The time it takes for 10 revolutions is 1.83 seconds.  What is the linear (tangential) velocity of the object?

A small mass, m, is attached through a tube to a larger hanging mass, M, with a weight of Mg. The small mass is set rotating in a horizontal circle with a radius of r. In terms of m, M, Mg and/or r, which of the following describes the equivalent value of the centripetal force acting on the small mass?

A small mass, m is attached through a tube to a larger hanging mass, M, with a weight of Mg. In terms of m, M, Mg, and/or r, which of the following describes the relationship used to calculate linear (tangential) velocity, v?

options.text: v = (Mgr /m) ½

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Watch the following video on camera recording techniques for physics investigations:

pageData.desc: Camera Recording Techniques—Physics

pageData.text: Create a work space.
Obtain the required materials.

Determine the mass of 1 small washer and the mass of 4 large washers. Record these values in Data Table 1 (If the masses of the washers are different, you will need to keep track of the appropriate mass for each washer.)

Construct the apparatus shown in .
  1. Slide the length of string through the polyethylene tube.
  2. Securely tie 1 small washer to one end of the string. Record the mass of the small washer in Data Table 2.
  3. Attach 1 large washer to the other end of the string. You can tie the large washer in place or fashion a hanger out of a paper clip. Make a loop at the end of the string for the paper clip hanger and place the large washer on the hanger. Record the mass of this large washer in Data Table 2.
  4. Attach a paper clip to the string on the end of the tube closest to the large washer such that it limits the length of string extending out of the other end of the tube (the end with the small washer) to approximately 30.0 cm (get as close to 30.0 cm as possible). You want the paper clip to stop the string at the end of the tube (closest to the large washer) when the length of string coming out of the other end of the tube (closest to the small washer) is approximately 30.0 cm (see Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: ruler next to a string with 3 paper clips attached at ~ 5 cm apart
pageData.altText: Figure 4: ruler next to a string with 3 paper clips attached at ~ 5 cm apart

pageData.text: 1. When the small washer is moving in a horizontal circle, the paper clip needs to stop the end of the string with the large washer from allowing more than ~30.0 cm of string from extending out the other end (small washer side) of the tube. The ~30.0 cm distance should be measured from the end of the polyethylene tube closest to the small washer to the center of mass (geometric center) of the small washer (see Figure 5).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Person working at a desk with a ruler laying parallel to a piece of string; the string has a piece of small tubing in the middle and a small washer attached at one end
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Person working at a desk with a ruler laying parallel to a piece of string; the string has a piece of small tubing in the middle and a small washer attached at one end

pageData.text: The ~30.0 cm length of string with the small washer represents the radius of the horizontal circle (Figure 6). Record the actual value of this length of string in Data Table 2 as the first r (radius).

pageData.desc: Figure 6: string showing large washer on one end with a ruler laying parallel to the string
pageData.altText: Figure 6: string showing large washer on one end with a ruler laying parallel to the string

pageData.text: Put on your eye protection (safety goggles).

Important Safety Note: When you test the apparatus and operate the apparatus for the investigation, take precautions to ensure the moving mass (small washer) will not come into contact with you, others, or any other items around you.

pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol
pageData.text: Record yourself testing your apparatus. Holding the polyethylene tube in your dominant hand, with the large washer end below your hand, extend your arm out from your body; rotate your hand and wrist to get the small washer moving in a horizontal circle (see Figure 7). The large washer should move up as a result of the motion but should stop by the paper clip when the string with the small washer has a radius of ~30.0 cm.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Human arm holding and operating centripetal acceleration apparatus
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Human arm holding and operating centripetal acceleration apparatus

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: If you will not be using a video to time the motion of the small washer moving in a horizontal circle, then you will need to get someone to take a picture of you with your apparatus as the small washer moves in a horizontal circle. This image will be included in your Lab Notebook.
When you have verified your apparatus functions properly, proceed to the activity portion of the lab.

In Activity 1, you will examine the effect of radius length and hanging mass on the linear velocity, <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> of washers moving in a horizontal circle. You will then graph and analyze the data to visualize these relationships.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Varying the Radius of the Moving Mass, m (9 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: Record and calculate values using SI units and the correct number of significant digits.For Part A of the investigation, you will change the radius of rotation of the small washer, keeping the moving mass constant and the hanging mass constant.

pageData.text: Hold the polyethylene tube in your dominant hand, large washer end below your hand, extend your arm out from your body; rotate your hand and wrist to get the small washer moving in a horizontal circle. When the string with the large washer has been stopped by the paper clip, maintain the motion of your hand and wrist so the small washer rotates in constant uniform motion. (Get the small washer moving in a horizontal circle or as close to a horizontal circle as possible; a little practice may be helpful.)

pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol
pageData.text: Begin recording video or timing the revolutions. Time the motion of the small washer long enough to ensure you have the amount of time it takes for 10 complete revolutions (full circles) of the small washer.

pageData.desc: play a video symbol
pageData.altText: play a video symbol
pageData.text: Play back your video to determine the time or obtain the time from your timing device for 10 complete revolutions of the small washer. Record this value in Data Table 2 as the first r (radius).

Place a second paper clip farther away from the large washer on the string such that it limits the length of string extending out of the other end of the tube (the end with the small washer) to ~25.0 cm. or as close as you can get to 25.0 cm. You want the paper clip to stop the string at the end of the tube (closest to the large washer) when the length of string coming out of the other end (closest to the small washer) of the tube is ~25.0 cm. The ~25.0 cm distance should be measured from the end of the polyethylene tube closest to the small washer to the center of mass (geometric center) of the small washer. Record the actual length of this part of the string in Data Table 2 as the second r (radius).
Repeat Steps 1–3 for the second radius of ~25.0 cm.

Place a third paper clip farther away from the large washer on the string such that it limits the length of string extending out of the other end of the tube (the end with the small washer) to ~20.0 cm. You want the paper clip to stop the string at the end of the tube (closest to the large washer) when the length of string coming out of the other end (closest to the small washer) of the tube is as close as possible to 20.0 cm. The ~20.0 cm distance should be measured from the end of the polyethylene tube closest to the small washer to the center of mass (geometric center) of the small washer. Record the actual length of this part of the string in Data Table 2 as the third r (radius).
Repeat Steps 1–3 for the third radius of ~20.0 cm.

Place a fourth paper clip farther away from the large washer on the string such that it limits the length of string extending out of the other end of the tube (the end with the small washer) to ~15.0 cm. You want the paper clip to stop the string at the end of the tube (closest to the large washer) when the length of string coming out of the other end (closest to the small washer) of the tube is as close to 15.0 cm. as possible. The ~15.0 cm distance should be measured from the end of the polyethylene tube closest to the small washer to the center of mass (geometric center) of the small washer. Record the actual length of this part of the string in Data Table 2 as the fourth r (radius).
Repeat Steps 1–3 for the fourth radius of ~15.0 cm.

typeBefore.text: For Part B of the investigation, you will change the hanging mass, keeping the radius of rotation of the small washer constant and moving mass constant.

pageData.text: Remove the second, third, and fourth paper clips you placed on the string closest to the large washer, keeping the first paper clip you placed on the string limiting the length of string extending out of the other end of the tube (small washer end) to ~30.0 cm.; verify this measurement and adjust if needed. Record the measured length of the string (for the radius of rotation for the small washer) in Data Table 3 as the radius for all four trials.

Transfer your data from Data Table 2 to the 1 LW (Large Washer) trial in Data Table 3. The parameters for the first trials are the same in Data Table 2 and Data Table 3, so this data can be reused rather than repeating measurements for this trial.

At the end of the string with the large washer, securely attach a second large washer to your paper clip hanger or tie another large washer to the string. Record, as the hanging mass, the total mass of the two large washers in Data Table 3 for the 2 LW trial.

Hold the polyethylene tube in your dominant hand, large washer end below your hand, extend your arm from your body; rotate your hand and wrist to get the small washer moving in a horizontal circle. When the string with the large washer has been stopped by the paper clip, maintain the motion of your hand and wrist so the small washer rotates in constant uniform motion.

pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol
pageData.text: Using your video recording device, begin timing the revolutions. Time the motion of the small washer long enough to ensure you have the amount of time it takes for 10 complete revolutions (full circles) of the small washer.

pageData.desc: play a video symbol
pageData.altText: play a video symbol
pageData.text: Playback your video to determine the time or obtain the time from your timing device for 10 complete revolutions of the small washer. Record this value in Data Table 3 for the 2 LW trial; a hanging mass of two large washers at a radius of rotation for the one small washer of ~30.0 cm.

At the end of the string with the large washers, securely attach a third large washer to your paper clip hanger or tie another large washer to the string. Record, as the hanging mass, the total mass of the 3 large washers in Data Table 3 for the 3 LW trial.
Repeat Steps 4–6 for a hanging mass of 3 large washers at a radius of rotation for the one small washer of ~30.0 cm.

At the end of the string with the large washers, securely attach a fourth large washer to your paper clip hanger or tie another large washer to the string. Record, as the hanging mass M, the total mass of the four large washers in Data Table 3 for the 4 LW trial.
Repeat Steps 4–6 for a hanging mass of four large washers at a radius of rotation for the one small washer of ~30.0 cm.

typeBefore.text: Note: Record and calculate values using SI units and the correct number of significant digits.

pageData.text: Calculate the experimental velocity, vE, for each trial in Data Table 2 and Data Table 3 using Equation 18. Record these values in the appropriate columns of the data tables.

pageData.desc: Equation 18: V sub E equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin paren 10 end paren 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin paren 20 end paren pi r over t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 18: V sub E equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin paren 10 end paren 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin paren 20 end paren pi r over t end fraction

pageData.text: Calculate the theoretical velocity, vT, for each trial in Data Table 2 and Data Table 3 using Equation 19. Record these values in the appropriate columns of the data tables.

pageData.desc: Equation 19: v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 19: v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root

pageData.text: Calculate the percent error in your velocity values by comparing the experimental value with the theoretical value for each trial in Data Table 2 and 3. Record these values in the appropriate columns of the data tables.
Transfer the radius and experimental velocity, vE2, values from Data Table 2 into Data Table 4.
Calculate and record the square of the experimental velocity, vE2, and record these values in Data Table 4.
Calculate and record the for each radius in Data Table 4.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table 4 of radius, r vs. (vE)2. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as x vs y.) On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Transfer the radius and experimental velocity, vE, values from Data Table 3 into Data Table 5.
Calculate and record the square of the experimental velocity, vE2, and record these values in Data Table 5.
Calculate and record the centripetal acceleration for each trial in Data Table 5.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the values in Data Table 5 of centripetal acceleration, ac vs (vE)2. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as x vs y.) On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Transfer the required data from Data Table 2 into Data Table 6.
Complete Data Table 6 by determining and recording vE2, mvE2, , Fc and Weight, FW.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table 6 of radius, r vs. mvE2. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as x vs y.) On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Transfer the required data from Data Table 3 into Data Table 7.
Complete Data Table 7 by determining and recording m/r, vE2, centripetal force, Fc, and weight, FW.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table 7 of vE2 vs centripetal force, Fc. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as x vs y.) On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.

In Extension Activity 1, you will examine the effect of changing the moving mass on the linear velocity, <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal acceleration</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>centripetal force</button> of washers moving in a horizontal circle. You will then graph and analyze the data to visualize these relationships.

text: Calculate the theoretical linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Measure the <button class='glossary-text'>angular frequency</button> of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Experimentally determine the linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle.
Calculate the percent error in the linear (tangential) velocity of a mass moving in a horizontal circle by comparing the theoretical and experimental values.
Evaluate how the centripetal acceleration experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the moving mass.
Evaluate how the centripetal force experienced by a mass moving in a horizontal circle is affected by changing the moving mass.
Electronic balance
Measuring tape or ruler
String ~ 35 inches (90 cm = 0.90 m)
2 Paper clips
4 Washers, small
Washer, large
Polyethylene tubing, 10 cm long
Timing device such as a stopwatch or stopwatch app
Cell phone (or comparable mobile device) for timing and taking video or pictures
Graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets
Optional, but recommended: a volunteer to assist you rotating the moving mass or with timing

pageData.text: Wear your safety goggles. Safety precautions must be taken, as the experiment involves rotating a mass in a horizontal circle.
pageData.desc: goggle symbol
pageData.altText: goggle symbol

pageData.text: Important Safety Note: When you operate the apparatus, take precautions to ensure the moving mass (small washers) will not come into contact with you or any other items around you.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

typeBefore.text: Note: Record and calculate values using SI units and the correct number of significant digits.

If you will not be using a video to time the motion of the small washer moving in a horizontal circle then you will need to have someone take a picture of you with your apparatus as the small washer moves in a horizontal circle for inclusion in your Lab Notebook.
In the Extension Activity, you will change the moving mass, keeping the radius of rotation of the small washer constant and the hanging mass constant.

pageData.text: Determine the mass of the 4 small washers (try to locate small washers with the same mass) and 1 large washer you will be using in the extension activity; record these values in Data Table E1.

By using the same large washer and small washer you used when you constructed your apparatus (during preparation), you will be able to transfer data rather than repeating trials. If you have the same washers, transfer the mass values for the 1 large washer and 1 small washer into Data Table E2.

You will be using the same apparatus you constructed in the lab preparation. If you continue to the extension activity after completing Part A and Part B of the investigation, start by removing the three large washers you added in Part B; returning your apparatus to the parameters you established during the investigation preparation: 1 large washer as the hanging mass, M; 1 small washer as the moving mass, m; and 1 paper clip positioned for a radius for the moving mass of ~30.0 cm.

If you are using the same large washer you used for Part I and the same moving mass you used for Part A and Part B; transfer the time data from the investigation Data Table 2 for one large washer at a radius of rotation for the small washer of ~30.0 cm into Data Table E2.

At the end of the string with the small washer, securely attach a second small washer to the string. (If needed, use an additional piece of string to tie the washers together.) Record, as the moving mass, the total mass of the 2 small washers in Data Table E2.

Hold the polyethylene tube in your dominant hand, large washer end below your hand, extend your arm; move your hand and wrist to get the small washers moving in a horizontal circle. When the large washer moves up and is stopped by the paper clip, maintain the motion of your hand and wrist so the small washers rotate in constant uniform motion.
Begin videoing or timing the revolutions. Continue to time the motion of the small washers ensuring you can determine the time for 10 complete revolutions.
pageData.desc: record a video symbol
pageData.altText: record a video symbol

pageData.text: Play your video or obtain the time from your timing device for 10 complete revolutions of the small washers. Record this time in Data Table E2.
pageData.desc: video link symbol
pageData.altText: video link symbol

pageData.text: At the end of the string with the small washers, securely attach a third small washer to the string. (If needed, use an additional piece of string to tie the washers together.) Record, as the moving mass, the total mass of the 3 small washers in the Data Table E2.
Repeat Steps 6–8 with a hanging mass of one large washer, a moving mass of 3 small washers at a radius of rotation for the small washers of ~30.0 cm.

At the end of the string with the small washers, securely attach a fourth small washer to the string. (If needed, use an additional piece of string to tie the washers together.) Record, as the moving mass, the total mass of the 4 small washers in Data Table E2.
Repeat Steps 6–8 with a hanging mass of 1 large washer, and a moving mass of 4 small washers at a radius of rotation for the small washers of ~30.0 cm.
Calculate and record the experimental velocity for each trial in Data Table E2.
Calculate and record the theoretical velocity for each trial in Data Table E2.
Calculate and record the percent error in your velocity values by comparing the experimental value with the theoretical value for each trial in Data Table E2.
Transfer the required data from Data Table E2 into Data Table E3. Complete the data table by squaring the velocity values and calculating .

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table E3 of centripetal acceleration vs vE2. (Note: variables are identified for graphing as x vs y.) On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Transfer the required data from Data Table E2 into Data Table E4.
Complete Data Table E4 by determining and recording vE2, r/m, , Fc, and Weight, FW.

Use a graphing program such as Excel or Google Sheets to create a graph using the data in Data Table E4 of (r/m) vs vE2. On the graph, insert a best fit line or curve and display the equation on the graph. Title the graph and label the axis with quantity and units. Consider whether the data point (0, 0) should be included on your graph; include the point (0, 0) if it agrees with the experiment and relationships between the variables.
Return the materials to the equipment kit and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.content: Equation 10.  Velocity of a particle in a circular path
pageData.desc: Equation 10: v equals begin fraction d r over d t end fraction equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket cosine omega t i plus sine omega t j end bracket equals
pageData.altText: Equation 10: v equals begin fraction d r over d t end fraction equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket cosine omega t i plus sine omega t j end bracket equals

pageData.content: Equation 11. Acceleration of a particle in a circular path
pageData.desc: Equation 11: a equals begin fraction dv over dt equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket minus r omega sine omega t i plus r omega cosine omega t j end bracket equals minus r omega sup 2 cosine omega t i minus r omega sup 2 sine omega t j
pageData.altText: Equation 11: a equals begin fraction dv over dt equals begin fraction d over dt end fraction begin bracket minus r omega sine omega t i plus r omega cosine omega t j end bracket equals minus r omega sup 2 cosine omega t i minus r omega sup 2 sine omega t j

pageData.content: Equation 12. Centripetal acceleration
pageData.desc: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat
pageData.altText: Equation 12: vector a sub c equals begin fraction negative vector v squared over r end fraction equals r hat

pageData.content: Equation 13. Centripetal force
pageData.desc: Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 13: F sub c equals ma sub c equals begin fraction mv sup 2 over r end fraction

pageData.content: Equation 14. Weight of an object
pageData.desc: Equation 14: Weight equals F sub w equals M times g
pageData.altText: Equation 14: Weight equals F sub w equals M times g

pageData.content: Equation 15. Centripetal force equals weight of hanging mass
pageData.desc: Equation 15: F sub c equals F sub w
pageData.altText: Equation 15: F sub c equals F sub w

pageData.desc: Equation 16: begin fraction m v squared over r end fraction equals M g yields v squared equals begin fraction M g r over m end fraction yields v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root
pageData.altText: Equation 16: begin fraction m v squared over r end fraction equals M g yields v squared equals begin fraction M g r over m end fraction yields v equals begin square root begin fraction M g r over m end fraction end square root

pageData.content: Equation 17. Linear velocity in terms of radius and time
pageData.desc: Equation 17: v equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 10 end parentheses times 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 20 end parentheses pi r over t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 17: v equals begin fraction N 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 10 end parentheses times 2 pi r over t end fraction equals begin fraction begin parentheses 20 end parentheses pi r over t end fraction

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, determine the mass of the washers, construct the apparatus, measure the string and test the apparatus. In activity 1, spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. Then, place a paper clip at the specified length to shorten the radius. Repeat the procedure at all specified radii. Next, reset the apparatus, add an additional washer and record the mass. Then, spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. Do this for 2, 3 and 4 washers. Next, calculate the percent difference for the experimental and theoretical velocities, Ve2 and centripetal acceleration. Finally, complete four graphs and analyze the data of each: r versus Ve2, centripetal acceleration versus Ve2, r versus m Ve2 and Ve2 versus centripetal force. Proceed to the extension activity if it is assigned.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram (cont... )
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for the extension activity for this investigation.  In the extension activity, you will reset the appartatus. Then, you will measure the mass of the small washers and add an additional small washer to the apparatus as a moving mass. Next, you will spin the apparatus in horizontal circles and determine the time it takes for the washer to complete 10 revolutions. When you have completed this for 2, 3 and 4 small wahsers, you will then calculate the percent difference for the experimental and theoretical velocities, Ve2 and centripetal acceleration.  Finally, complete two graphs and analyze the data of each: centripetal acceleration versus Ve2, and r/m versus  Ve2.

data.title: Angular displacement
data.content: A definite amount of rotation about a specific axis

data.title: Angular frequency
data.content: The frequency of a periodic process expressed in radians per second

data.title: Angular velocity
data.content: The rate of change of angular displacement with respect to time

data.title: Centripetal acceleration
data.content: Moving or tending to move toward the center

data.title: Centripetal force
data.content: A force produced by centripetal acceleration

data.title: Linear acceleration
data.content: The change in velocity with respect to time

data.title: Newton's first law of motion
data.content: States that an object at rest or in uniform motion will continue to be at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a net external force

data.title: Newton's second law of motion
data.content: States that the force acting on an object is related to the change in the object’s momentum (Δp), which is the product of the object’s mass (m) multiplied by its acceleration (a)

data.title: Period
data.content: The inverse of the wave frequency; the time it takes for one full wavelength to pass
